instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: Again, A Retina MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange light, missing S4 Rails.
threads.message:
Ok, here we go again, i have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (Again) missing all s4 and obviously S3,S0 Rails.
The last time i post one here and we could not solve. so, again.. thats my measures.


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is present. i little bit fluctuant like 12.48.. 12,49.. 12,55.. 12,56.. (i think this is trying to get power on)
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> Is present
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> present
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> present
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> missing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> missing.

missing <SIGNAL>PM_SPL_S5_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> too

this board is pretty clean, no corrosion, no liquid damage.

SPI Bios area looks good, and i measure this signals too
<SIGNAL>PCH_SUSACK_L</SIGNAL> Present
<SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> = 0.20v (wierd)
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> = Missing
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> missing
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> missing
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> Present
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> Present
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> Present.

i want to know what could i do..

threads.title: Again, A Retina MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange light, missing S4 Rails.
threads.message: <SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> present? Checked the usual corrosion points, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>/50 <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and termination resistors and traces? Check for power cycling on <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL>

threads.title: Again, A Retina MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange light, missing S4 Rails.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 26326"]<SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> present? Checked the usual corrosion points, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>/50 <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and termination resistors and traces? Check for power cycling on <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL>[/QUOTE]

<SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> Is present, No corrosion on <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> neither. what do u mean with "power cycling" ? i checked <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> for a long time to see if this for a second gets high but never appears.

threads.title: Again, A Retina MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange light, missing S4 Rails.
threads.message:
If it power cycles it will not be a second. If you have a slow multimeter it will never pick it up. Use a scope or connect a LED+resistor to see the pulses. 
What is the history of this machine? Checked rails for shorts?

threads.title: Again, A Retina MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange light, missing S4 Rails.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 26379"]If it power cycles it will not be a second. If you have a slow multimeter it will never pick it up. Use a scope or connect a LED+resistor to see the pulses.
What is the history of this machine? Checked rails for shorts?[/QUOTE]

Hello, thanks for the answers. i soldered a led attached to <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> and never get any pulse at this line. no shorted to ground on <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V_S4</SIGNAL> Neither.

what do you think?

threads.title: Again, A Retina MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange light, missing S4 Rails.
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> present? Did you solder a resistor is serie with the LED, else the LED got 5V and is dead now of course, polarity of LED correct?

threads.title: Again, A Retina MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange light, missing S4 Rails.
threads.message: Yeah, <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is present. The led is fine, i solder 1 pin of resistor to ground, another pin of resistor to cathode of the led diode, and the anode attached to <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL>. i know the diode is fine cause i try again with a power supply with 5v. and it's fine. the resistor is a 100 Ohms resistor.

threads.title: Again, A Retina MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange light, missing S4 Rails.
threads.message: OK, assuming you are using a good 60W or 80W charger the most likely thing would be SMC/crap under SMC. Check 32KHz from <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> also.

threads.title: Again, A Retina MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange light, missing S4 Rails.
threads.message: Ok, to check this i need an oscilloscope right? another question is, i have a same board but, with some differences. the board to repair have 16GB Ram, and that donor board have 8 or 4Gb ram. i can replace the smc from the donor?

threads.title: Again, A Retina MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange light, missing S4 Rails.
Again, A Retina MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange light, missing S4 Rails.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 26461"]3536 and 3476 are the same.[/QUOTE]

Ok, and about the oscilloscope, i need one to get mensures like 32Khz right?

threads.title: Again, A Retina MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green/Orange light, missing S4 Rails.
threads.message: Some multimeters have a frequency counter up to 40kHz. If not then either get a scope or multimeter with counter.
